title: 103_hr4789
content: The Act is known as the "Morris K. Udall Parkinson's Research, Education, and Assistance Act of 1994". It includes findings and purpose statements. Parkinson's disease, affecting 1.5 million Americans, causes dopamine-producing cells to degenerate, leading to tremors and loss of motor function. It affects 40% of patients under 60, eventually rendering them unable to care for themselves and placing strain on families. The text chunk discusses the significant financial burden of Parkinson's disease on society, with an estimated annual cost of nearly $6 billion. It highlights the lack of funding for research, with only $30 million allocated specifically for Parkinson's research. The purpose of the Act is to expand and coordinate research on Parkinson's, as well as improve care for patients and their caregivers. SEC. 485G. PARKINSON'S DISEASE RESEARCH. This section amends the Public Health Service Act to add a new subpart focused on Parkinson's Disease Research. The Director of the National Institutes of Health establishes a council to coordinate Parkinson's research activities, including key members and representatives from various departments and agencies. The council will convene a National Consensus Conference on Parkinson's Disease and Related Neurodegenerative Disorders to aid in development. The Secretary, in consultation with a council, develops a coordinated research agenda for degenerative disorders. This includes establishing 10 Parkinson's Research Centers to conduct research on the cause, prevention, treatment, and management of Parkinson's. The Secretary may award feasibility study grants to support the dissemination of clinical information, patient care services, training for healthcare personnel, research coordination, tissue bank development, and community awareness for Parkinson's. The Secretary will establish a grant program to support scientists in Parkinson's research, enabling established investigators to conduct research and encouraging the development of new investigators. Additionally, a registry will be established for screening and collecting patient and family data. A registry will be established for screening and collecting patient and family data related to Parkinson's. The Secretary may award grants for training and education in Parkinson's care, ensuring appropriate geographic coverage. Additionally, a national education program will be established to improve care for individuals with Parkinson's. The legislation aims to support organizations in providing care for individuals with Parkinson's, offering technical assistance to organizations aiding families, and establishing a clearinghouse for research dissemination. Eligibility for grants requires submitting an application to the Secretary. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these activities. The legislation authorizes appropriations of $75 million for 1996, $100 million for 1997, $200 million for 1998, and necessary sums for 1999 and 2000. The Secretary will allocate funds for establishing centers and providing technical assistance to organizations. For feasibility study grants, leadership and excellence awards, patient and family registries, and health professions training programs, appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 1996 to 2000. For health professions training programs, $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1996, $5,000,000 for fiscal year 1997, and $8,000,000 for fiscal year 1998. For the National Parkinson's Disease Education Program, $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1996, $3,000,000 for fiscal year 1997, and $4,000,000 for fiscal year 1998.
